custom_item_1.info:
Banner notifications can be implemented using messages or warning banners displayed before individuals log in to target systems.

  It is recommended a banner is set to your approved organization content.
custom_item_1.solution:
The command to set a banner is as follows

switch:admin> bannerset "My banner"

or

switch:admin> bannerset
Please input context of security banner (press "." RETURN at the beginning of a newline to finish input):

custom_item_2.info:
Banner notifications can be implemented using messages or warning banners displayed before individuals log in to target systems.

  It is recommended a banner is set to your approved organization content.
custom_item_2.solution:
The command to set a MOTD banner is as follows

switch:admin> motd --set "This is a chassis-level banner. It displays before the login."

custom_item_3.info:
Telnet is enabled by default.

  To prevent passing clear text passwords over the network when connecting to the switch, you can block the Telnet protocol using an IP Filter policy
custom_item_3.solution:
The command to disable Telnet is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 23 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_4.info:
Telnet is enabled by default.

  To prevent passing clear text passwords over the network when connecting to the switch, you can block the Telnet protocol using an IP Filter policy
custom_item_4.solution:
The command to disable Telnet is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 23 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_5.info:
SSH uses asymmetric authentication to exchange keys and create a secure encrypted session.

  It is recommended that you use Secure Shell (SSH) instead of Telnet.
custom_item_5.solution:
The command to enable SSH is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 22 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_6.info:
SSH uses asymmetric authentication to exchange keys and create a secure encrypted session.

  It is recommended that you use Secure Shell (SSH) instead of Telnet.
custom_item_6.solution:
The command to enable SSH is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 22 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_7.info:
The HTTP interface that is started by default has the same limitations as Telnet.

  It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.
custom_item_7.solution:
The command to disable HTTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 80 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_8.info:
The HTTP interface that is started by default has the same limitations as Telnet.

  It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.
custom_item_8.solution:
The command to disable HTTP is as follows

 switch:admin> seccertutil genkey

 Generating a new key pair will automatically do the following:

 1. Delete all existing CSRs.

 2. Delete all existing certificates.

 3. Reset the certificate filename to none.

 4. Disable secure protocols.

 Continue (yes, y, no, n): [no] y

 Select key size [1024 or 2048]: 1024

 Generating new rsa public/private key pair

 Done.

custom_item_9.info:
The HTTP interface that is started by default has the same limitations as Telnet.

  It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.
custom_item_9.solution:
The command to disable HTTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 80 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_10.info:
It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.

  HTTPS is HTTP traffic running over a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
custom_item_10.solution:
The command to enable HTTPS is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 443 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_11.info:
It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.

  HTTPS is HTTP traffic running over a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
custom_item_11.solution:
The command to enable HTTPS is as follows

 switch:admin> seccertutil genkey

 Generating a new key pair will automatically do the following:

 1. Delete all existing CSRs.

 2. Delete all existing certificates.

 3. Reset the certificate filename to none.

 4. Disable secure protocols.

 Continue (yes, y, no, n): [no] y

 Select key size [1024 or 2048]: 1024

 Generating new rsa public/private key pair

 Done.

custom_item_12.info:
HTTPS is HTTP traffic running over a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).

  Ensure the HTTP ssl logs are enabled.
custom_item_12.solution:
The command to enable HTTPS is as follows

 switch:admin> seccertutil genkey

 Generating a new key pair will automatically do the following:

 1. Delete all existing CSRs.

 2. Delete all existing certificates.

 3. Reset the certificate filename to none.

 4. Disable secure protocols.

 Continue (yes, y, no, n): [no] y

 Select key size [1024 or 2048]: 1024

 Generating new rsa public/private key pair

 Done.

custom_item_13.info:
It is recommended that the HTTPS interface be configured and the HTTP interface be disabled.

  HTTPS is HTTP traffic running over a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
custom_item_13.solution:
The command to enable HTTPS is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 443 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_14.info:
TFTP client and server should be disabled as they do not require any authentication.

  Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) and Secure Copy Protocol (SCP) are recommended as they are part of the SSH protocol suite.
custom_item_14.solution:
The command to disable TFTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 69 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_15.info:
TFTP client and server should be disabled as they do not require any authentication.

  Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) and Secure Copy Protocol (SCP) are recommended as they are part of the SSH protocol suite.
custom_item_15.solution:
The command to disable TFTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 69 -proto

 tcp -act deny

custom_item_16.info:
Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) and Secure Copy Protocol (SCP) are part of the SSH protocol suite.

  They provide an encrypted session using public/private keys between client and server.
custom_item_16.solution:
The command to enable SFTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 115 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_17.info:
Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) and Secure Copy Protocol (SCP) are part of the SSH protocol suite.

  They provide an encrypted session using public/private keys between client and server.
custom_item_17.solution:
The command to enable SFTP is as follows

 switch:admin> ipfilter --addrule policy_name -rule rule_number -sip any -dp 115 -proto

 tcp -act permit

custom_item_18.description: Brocade - minimum number of lowercase characters set to 1
custom_item_18.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The minimum number of lowercase characters that must appear in the password must be set to 1 or greater.
custom_item_18.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -lowercase 1

custom_item_19.description: Brocade - minimum number of uppercase characters set to 1
custom_item_19.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The minimum number of uppercase characters that must appear in the password must be set to 1 or greater.
custom_item_19.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -uppercase 1

custom_item_20.description: Brocade - minimum number of numeric digits set to 1
custom_item_20.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The minimum number of numeric digits that must appear in the password must be set to 1 or greater.
custom_item_20.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -digits 1

custom_item_21.description: Brocade - minimum number of punctuation characters set to 1
custom_item_21.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The minimum number of punctuation character that must appear in the password must be set to 1 or greater.
custom_item_21.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -punctuation 1

custom_item_22.description: Brocade - minimum length of the password must be set to 9
custom_item_22.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The minimum length of the password must be set to 9.
custom_item_22.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -minlength 9

custom_item_23.description: Brocade - repeat characters must be set to 1
custom_item_23.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The length of repeated character sequences must be set to 1.
custom_item_23.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -repeat 1

custom_item_24.description: Brocade - sequential characters must be set to 2
custom_item_24.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The length of sequential character sequences must be set to 2.
custom_item_24.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -sequence 2

custom_item_25.description: Brocade - password history must be set to 1
custom_item_25.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  The password history policy prevents users from recycling recently used passwords.
custom_item_25.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -history 1

custom_item_26.description: Brocade - minimum password age must be set to at least 30 days
custom_item_26.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  Specifies the minimum number of days that must elapse before a user can change a password.
custom_item_26.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -minpasswordage 30

custom_item_27.description: Brocade - maximum password age must be set to no more than 60 days
custom_item_27.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  Specifies the maximum number of days that can elapse before a password must be changed.
custom_item_27.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -maxpasswordage 60

custom_item_28.description: Brocade - password warning must be set to at least 30 days
custom_item_28.info:
The password strength policy is enforced across all user accounts, and enforces a set of format rules to which new passwords must adhere.

  Specifies the maximum number of days that can elapse before a password must be changed.
custom_item_28.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -warning 30

custom_item_29.info:
The account lockout policy disables a user account when that user exceeds a specified number of failed login attempts, and is enforced across all user accounts.

  The admin account lockout policy must be enabled and uses the same lockout threshold as the other permissions.
custom_item_29.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --enableadminlockout

custom_item_30.info:
The account lockout policy disables a user account when that user exceeds a specified number of failed login attempts, and is enforced across all user accounts.

  Specifies the number of times a user can attempt to log in using an incorrect password before the account is locked.
custom_item_30.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -lockoutthreshold 3

custom_item_31.description: Brocade - lockout duration set to 30 minutes
custom_item_31.info:
The account lockout policy disables a user account when that user exceeds a specified number of failed login attempts, and is enforced across all user accounts.

  Specifies the time, in minutes, after which a previously locked account is automatically unlocked.
custom_item_31.solution:
Password authentication policies configured using the passwdCfg command

 swd77:admin> passwdcfg --set -lockoutduration 30

custom_item_32.description: Brocade - administrator account is enabled with admin role assigned
custom_item_32.info:
Role-Based Action Control (RBAC) specifies the permissions that a user account has based on the role the account has been assigned.

  The role that your account is associated with determines the level of access you have on that switch and in the fabric.
custom_item_32.solution:
User configuration policies are configured using the userconfig command command

 swd77:admin> userconfig --change admin -e yes

 swd77:admin> userconfig --change root -r admin

custom_item_33.description: Brocade - root account is enabled with root role assigned
custom_item_33.info:
Role-Based Action Control (RBAC) specifies the permissions that a user account has based on the role the account has been assigned.

  The role that your account is associated with determines the level of access you have on that switch and in the fabric.
custom_item_33.solution:
User configuration policies are configured using the userconfig command

 swd77:admin> userconfig --change root -e yes

 swd77:admin> userconfig --change root -r root

custom_item_34.info:
Federal information processing standards (FIPS) specify the security standards to be satisfied by a cryptographic module utilized in Fabric OS v6.0.0 and later to protect sensitive information in the switch.

  FIPS mode, when enabled, is a chassis-wide setting that affects all logical switches. Once enabled, FIPS mode cannot be disabled.
custom_item_34.solution:
FIPS can be enabled using the fipscfg command

 swd77:admin> fipscfg --enable fips

custom_item_35.info:
SCP encrypts data during transfer, thereby avoiding packet sniffers that attempt to extract useful information during data transfer.

  Enables secure configuration upload or download.
custom_item_35.solution:
configurechassis command changes chassis-level system configuration settings

 switch:admin> configurechassis

cfgload attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no] y

 Enforce secure config Upload/Download (yes, y, no, n): [no]y

 Enforce signature validation for firmware (yes, y, no, n): [no]

 Add Suffix to the uploaded file name (yes, y, no, n): [no]

Custom attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no]

system attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no]

custom_item_36.description: Brocade - Enforce signature validation for firmware
custom_item_36.info:
This setting ensures that firmware packages are valid.

  Enables signature validation enforcement.
custom_item_36.solution:
configurechassis command changes chassis-level system configuration settings

 switch:admin> configurechassis

cfgload attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no] y

 Enforce secure config Upload/Download (yes, y, no, n): [no]

 Enforce signature validation for firmware (yes, y, no, n): [no]y

 Add Suffix to the uploaded file name (yes, y, no, n): [no]

Custom attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no]

system attributes (yes, y, no, n): [no]

custom_item_37.info:
POST includes two phases: POST Phase I mainly tests hardware and POST Phase II tests system functionality.

  Use the diagPost command to display the current POST status.
custom_item_37.solution:
To enable POST:

 switch:admin> diagenablepost

 Config update Succeeded

 Diagnostic POST is now enabled

custom_item_38.info:
This setting enables audit logging and to display the audit log configuration.

  When managing SANs you may want to audit certain classes of events to ensure that you can view and generate an audit log for what is happening on a switch, particularly for security-related event changes.
custom_item_38.solution:
To enable audit logging:

 switch:admin> auditcfg --enable

 Audit filter is enabled

custom_item_39.description: Brocade - Configures filters for a specified audit class
custom_item_39.info:
This setting sets filters by configuring certain classes, to add or remove any of the classes in the filter list, to set severity levels for audit messages.

  These events include login failures, zone configuration changes, firmware downloads, and other configuration changes.
custom_item_39.solution:
To configure the audit log filter:

 switch:admin> auditcfg --class 1,2,3

 Audit filter is configured

custom_item_40.description: Brocade - All audit severity level must be audited
custom_item_40.info:
When severity is set, only log messages of type severity_level and higher are displayed.

  Valid values are INFO, WARNING, ERROR, and CRITICAL.
custom_item_40.solution:
To configure the audit log severity:

 switch:admin> auditcfg --severity critical

custom_item_41.description: Brocade - Forward all error logs to syslog daemon
custom_item_41.info:
configure a switch to forward all error log entries to the syslog daemon (syslogd) of one or more specified servers.

  The syslog daemon is a process available on most UNIX systems that reads and forwards system messages to the appropriate log files or user.
custom_item_41.solution:
To add an IP address to the list of machines to which system messages are sent:

 switch:admin> syslogdipadd 1080::8:800:200C:417A

 switch:admin> syslogdipshow

 syslog.1 1080::8:800:200C:417A

custom_item_42.description: Brocade - The idle timeout for login session set to 30 minutes
custom_item_42.info:
Users are logged out after 30 minutes of inactivity.

  The execution of this command is subject to Virtual Fabric or Admin Domain restrictions that may be in place.
custom_item_42.solution:
To configure the audit log severity:

 switch:admin> timeout 10

 IDLE Timeout Changed to 10 minutes

 The modified IDLE Timeout will be in effect after NEXT login

custom_item_43.description: Brocade - Ensure a SSL certificate file is established
custom_item_43.info:
Configure SSL by obtaining, installing, and activating digital certificates for SSL support.

  In order for HTTPS to become enabled there must be an SSL certificate established.
custom_item_43.solution:
To import a PKI-based certificate

 switch:admin> seccertutil import -config swcert

custom_item_44.description: Brocade - Authentication policy must be rejected
custom_item_44.info:
The authentication (AUTH) policy allows you to configure DH-CHAP authentication on switches with Fabric OS.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_44.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the Auth policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'AUTH'

custom_item_45.description: Brocade - Switch Connection Control policy must be rejected
custom_item_45.info:
The switch connection control (SCC) policy is used to restrict which switches can join the fabric.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_45.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the SCC policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'SCC'

custom_item_46.description: Brocade - Fabric Configuration Server policy must be rejected
custom_item_46.info:
When the FCS policy is created, the WWN of the local switch is automatically included in the FCS list.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_46.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the FCS policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'FCS'

custom_item_47.description: Brocade - Device Connection Control policy must be rejected
custom_item_47.info:
Multiple DCC policies can be used to restrict which device ports can connect to which switch ports.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_47.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the DCC policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'DCC'

custom_item_48.description: Brocade - IPfilter policy must be rejected
custom_item_48.info:
The IP Filter policy is a set of rules applied to the IP management interfaces as a packet filtering firewall.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_48.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the IPfilter policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'IPFILTER'

custom_item_49.description: Brocade - Fabric Element Authentication must be rejected
custom_item_49.info:
The Fabric Element Authentication (PWD) policy is a set of authentication measures the switch uses to authenticate users.

  By setting the policy to reject protects local switch from distributions of databases from other switches.
custom_item_49.solution:
To configure the switch to reject distribution of the PWD policy

 switch:admin> fddcfg --localreject 'PWD'

custom_item_50.description: Brocade - Bottleneck detection must be enabled
custom_item_50.info:
Enabling bottleneck detection enables both latency and congestion detection.

  When you enable bottleneck detection on a switch, the settings are applied to all eligible ports on that switch.
custom_item_50.solution:
To configure bottleneck detection on brocade switch

 switch:admin> bottleneckmon --enable

custom_item_51.description: Brocade - Bottleneck alerts must be enabled
custom_item_51.info:
Enables alerts when configured thresholds are exceeded on the ports that are enabled for bottleneck detection.

  When enabled the command triggers an SNMP and a RASlog alert when the ports on the configured switch experience latency or congestion.
custom_item_51.solution:
To configure bottleneck alerts on brocade switch

 switch:admin> bottleneckmon --enable -alert

custom_item_52.description: Brocade - Brocade licenses must not be expired
custom_item_52.info:
Ensuring licenses are valid and timely updates are applied helps to remediate vulnerabilities or technical issues in the appliance.

  Expired licenses have an output string of License has expired.
custom_item_52.solution:
To display the license keys on a switch

 switch:admin> licenseshow

custom_item_53.info:
A periodic review of users with administrative privileges ensures that organizational changes are reflected in the device configuration.

  The administration account has access to all administration duties and administrative commands.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_53.solution:
To display all account information for a switch

 switch:admin> userconfig --show -a

custom_item_54.info:
Review all enabled accounts, and make sure there are no unauthorized accounts enabled.

  NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.
custom_item_54.solution:
To display all account information for a switch

 switch:admin> userconfig --show -a

custom_item_55.description: Brocade - Review the NTP server configuration
custom_item_55.info:
Ensuring that approved NTP servers are used.

  When multiple NTP server addresses are passed, tsClockServer sets the first obtainable address as the active NTP server.
custom_item_55.solution:
Setting the ntp server on a Brocade switch

 switch:admin> tsclockserver ip_address

custom_item_56.description: Brocade - Enable the track changes feature
custom_item_56.info:
The track changes feature allows you to keep a record of specific changes that may not be considered switch events.

  The output from the track changes feature is dumped to the system messages log for the switch.
custom_item_56.solution:
To enable the track changes feature on Brocade switch

 switch:admin> trackchangesset 1

custom_item_57.description: Brocade - Enable the track changes feature for SNMP traps
custom_item_57.info:
The track changes feature allows you to keep a record of specific changes that may not be considered switch events.

  Specify 1 to enable sending messages to the SNMP-TRAP in addition to the error log.
custom_item_57.solution:
To enable the track changes SNMP trap mode feature on Brocade switch

 switch:admin> trackchangesset 1,1

custom_item_58.description: Brocade - SupportFTP parameters are set to SCP
custom_item_58.info:
When uploading a configuration file the user must use SCP.

  Ensure SCP is enabled for uploading files.
custom_item_58.solution:
To enable SCP on Brocade switch

 switch:admin> supportftp -s

custom_item_59.description: Brocade - SCP server host is approved
custom_item_59.info:
When uploading a configuration file the user must use SCP.

  Ensure the SCP server is approved by your organization.
custom_item_59.solution:
To enable SCP on Brocade switch

 switch:admin> supportftp -s

custom_item_60.description: Brocade - Set SNMP security level to authentication and privacy
custom_item_60.info:
Recipients for SNMP traps are restricted according to security levels.

  With authentication and privacy enabled SNMPv1 is not allowed and only SNMPv3 users with authPriv are allowed.
custom_item_60.solution:
To enable SNMP security level authentication and privacy

 switch:admin>  snmpconfig --set seclevel

custom_item_61.description: Brocade - SNMPv3 trap targets are configured properly
custom_item_61.info:
An unsolicited message that comes to the management station from the SNMP agent on the device is called a trap.

  Brocade switches send traps out on UDP port 162 and to any configured port.
custom_item_61.solution:
To configure SNMPv3 traps

 switch:admin> snmpconfig --set snmpv3

custom_item_62.description: Brocade - SNMPv3 uses SHA over MD5
custom_item_62.info:
If SNMP v3 users are configured, they can use either MD5 or SHA for authentication.

  The Secure Hash Algorithm is more secure than MD5.
custom_item_62.solution:
To configure SNMPv3 authentication protocol

 switch:admin> snmpconfig --set snmpv3

custom_item_63.description: Brocade - SNMP v3 uses AES instead of DES
custom_item_63.info:
It is recommended that SNMPv3 uses AES-128 over DES for confidentiality.

  Advanced Encryption Standard is a 128- or 256-bit fixed block size cipher.
custom_item_63.solution:
To configure SNMPv3 privilege protocol

 switch:admin> snmpconfig --set snmpv3
